I inferred to my boss that it could be confusing to clients if we present our advertising and digital departments as separate. “What?”, he snapped “It couldn’t be clearer?” — not like “that’s a unique perspective, explain more please” — but more like an alligator that noticed there was a small bird within reach of his snout.

That’s my experience in traditional advertising as a digital creative. Surrounded by people that think differently but don’t know that we think differently, more just think that I’m crazy. I learned a ton moving from digital to traditional, above-the-line advertising — it was an incredible education.

Conceptual creatives that think social/mobile first — don’t fit into a traditional agency environment

Traditional agencies think “digital” is websites and banners — that’s why they’re dying

I’m writing this from a rustic yet contemporary coffee shop, one of many sprinkled around San Francisco, littered with laptops and hipsters. My apartment has a view of the city, but I can’t work in the same place, day after day anymore — I’ve been doing it my entire career — over 10 years straight.

My apartment in Twin Peaks, overlooking the Mission

There’s no more rewarding a job than being a creative in advertising unless you like to travel, or value your time… or enjoy sleep.

Time for a break

I remember listening to The-4-Hour-Work-Week audiobook in the summer of 2010, when I lived in L.A., some 4 years ago. It was a guide to escaping your 9-5 job in favor of creating revenue streams independent of your time, so that you could roam the earth. It was written for people like me.

That summer I would jog, ride my bike, or lift weights getting all pumped up to the words of the author, Tim Ferris. Imagine if Rocky were an entrepreneur, that’s how I felt. It’s ironic that I listened to that book while exercising because it kicked off a point where I became so inspired that I no longer had time for extra things like a robust social life, or exercise! But then again I’m a creative and we’ve never been good at balance.

The next few years I obsessively planned ways to contribute to society that would generate a revenue stream. I started a t-shirt business called Modern Nerd, and began writing a book called Design Like a Strategist, both of which have been awesomely rewarding.

At one point I rented a second office because I got tired of working from home on evenings and weekends. All my projects started strong then idled due to time constraints and burn out from my full-time gig.

Here I am on ‘vacatioin’ in Vegas
Not belonging to an agency this past week, has been awesome.

My typical day this past week saw a handful of hours working, the rest of it spent exercising and catching up with friends, or as some would call it… “networking”. I’ve seen more of San Francisco in the past week than I have in the previous 10 months.

Now I have a different perspective. A perspective fueled by someone with an entrepreneur deep inside me, someone that doesn’t need to jump back into the 9–5 work force any time soon. Someone that values the potential of his time more than a paycheck.

Mid-day meeting with my roof

This past week of unemployment has been the closest thing to my dreams of being a digital nomad since I first listened to that audio book years ago. All it took was leaving my job.

I’m going to spend the next couple months traveling, focussing on getting as fit as possible (because I miss that feeling), and building enduring relationships that I can nurture and grow.

I intend to cruise around Asia writing my book — “Design Like a Strategist”.

Just like I learned an incredible amount in the last 8 months at a traditional agency, I can’t imagine how much I’ll learn writing a book while trotting the globe.

Me, the moment it clicked that leaving my job meant I could pursue my dreams

If my book sucks, I’ll have the peace of mind that I followed through on my commitments, and I’ll return with more perspective, experience, and a renewed energy.

Here’s to forks in the road leading to chasing your dreams.
